answers.author: Derek Johnson
answers.text:
Jesse,
Attached is a 2007 report by California Rural Legal Assistance and PolicyLink that provides an in-depth analysis of low-income,unincorporated rural communities within San Joaquin Valley. Specifically addressed in the report are shortcomings and deficiencies in infrastructure and services such as water, sewers, roads, housing, etc. Of particular interest might be the section where they discuss the the lack of comprehensive documentation that currently exists about infrastructure deficiencies in unincorporated communities. 
See also this June 2008 report commissioned by the West Central Community Development Group in New Mexico on transitioning an unincorporated community into a municipality. Several of the example communities they cite dealt with a fair amount of infrastructure problems as well during their transitions.
http://bit.ly/a1nHu7
A quick Google search using the right keywords may also be helpful in tracking down other examples. Hopefully this is enough to get you started. Good luck.
Derek Johnson

author: Jesse Martinez
text:
I will shortly be assisting an established statewide rural development nonprofit’s programs.
They have a variety of programs assisting the rural poor (including farm worker, community outreach, educational training, direct legal service, and, safe and healthy environment.
It appears that initially I’ll be evaluating their program on assisting unincorporated communities that lack basic infrastructure (e.g., sidewalks, parks, streetlights) and their reliable access to public services as well as other areas of interest.
Can you all direct me to helpful resources?
Regards,
Jesse Martinez
San Francisco
title: evaluating unincorporated communities
